snippet.textDisplay:
I love that you're being open about periods and share that you use a menstrual cup. I do wish you hadn't used the word "weird" to describe them however as I fear people will see this as a jokey video and not see these as serious options. I use reusable period underwear (ones you bleed into not as backup) and reusable cloth pads and it's the best thing I ever did for the comfort of my body and the environment too. They say disposables have chemicals in that encourage bleeding and I didn't really believe that but since I switched my periods last 3 days instead of 5.
As for washing the pants you have to check with each brand what the manufacturer advises but I put mine on a rinse cycle then wash at 40 degrees with just detergent no fabric conditioner.
snippet.textOriginal:
I love that you're being open about periods and share that you use a menstrual cup. I do wish you hadn't used the word "weird" to describe them however as I fear people will see this as a jokey video and not see these as serious options. I use reusable period underwear (ones you bleed into not as backup) and reusable cloth pads and it's the best thing I ever did for the comfort of my body and the environment too. They say disposables have chemicals in that encourage bleeding and I didn't really believe that but since I switched my periods last 3 days instead of 5.
As for washing the pants you have to check with each brand what the manufacturer advises but I put mine on a rinse cycle then wash at 40 degrees with just detergent no fabric conditioner.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the period pants are for helping with leaks maybe? Like if you don't change your pad/tampon in time and end up leaking a little, the pants are absorbent enough to stop it from showing through on your trousers/skirt. I have seen pants like what you're thinking of - Safiya Nygaard tested them out, with varying results (depended on how heavy she was) - but I think the ones you bought are just for helping with leaks.
snippet.textOriginal: I think the period pants are for helping with leaks maybe? Like if you don't change your pad/tampon in time and end up leaking a little, the pants are absorbent enough to stop it from showing through on your trousers/skirt. snippet.textDisplay:
Pads as shown on the packaging, you use the packaging of the next pad to throw away the worn one. It's much better than wasting toilet paper too on each one, just use toilet paper for the last pad you put on. Tampons should NOT be flushed down the toilet much like you wouldn't with a pad or nappies etc. They clog the drains and costs a lot of money to get blockages sorted and as you'd imagine it wouldn't be a nice job for the poor person who has to sort that... also tampons are one of our worst polluters and there's much more chance of it ended up in our ocean.

Some girls can have really heavy periods and leak wearing a tampon/ pad so those underwear could be great for them or just for some more security maybe for sleeping in or to not have that worry of leaking on your clothing.


Also with those sea sponges, Jazz says that they can cause TSS (toxic shock syndrome) also bear in mind that tampons also can cause that. Bacteria from the sea doesn't sound too good! xD
snippet.textOriginal:

Some girls can have really heavy periods and leak wearing a tampon/ pad so those underwear could be great for them or just for some more security maybe for sleeping in or to not have that worry of leaking on your clothing.

snippet.textDisplay:
For the situations when you're at your friend's house and their bin is weird for whatever reason I carry around plastic sacks or zip lock bags and you can wrap the tampon or the sponge in toilet paper, put it in the baggy and throw it into the bin. It's just that simple 🤷🏻‍♀️
And the panties are actually really great because so many people, including me, have a heavier flow especially during the night if anything were to happen.

snippet.textDisplay: I use my cup and period panties together, but when I'm just spotting I then only use my panties. To wash I just throw them in the sink and rinse, but they're never full, however I also use reusable pads. I've used the cup, pads and undies for 7 years without ever leaking. With tampons I wear pads too and I do wrap them in tp in public or my pad wrapper if I'm at home. I cramp less and have shorter lighter periods since switching to all reusable products and gotten away from the fragrance and dyes.
snippet.textOriginal: I use my cup and period panties together, but when I'm just spotting I then only use my panties. To wash I just throw them in the sink and rinse, but they're never full, however I also use reusable pads. I've used the cup, pads and undies for 7 years without ever leaking. With tampons I wear pads too and I do wrap them in tp in public or my pad wrapper if I'm at home. I cramp less and have shorter lighter periods since switching to all reusable products and gotten away from the fragrance and dyes.

snippet.textDisplay: When I’ve used disposable products I used to keep a ziplock sandwich bag in my handbag and I’d wrap pads up in the wrapper of the new pad and then in a tissue and pop in my ziplock bag when I was out. Then I’d throw them out when I got home. I’d imagine I’d do the same with tampons if I were to go back to disposables.
snippet.textOriginal: When I’ve used disposable products I used to keep a ziplock sandwich bag in my handbag and I’d wrap pads up in the wrapper of the new pad and then in a tissue and pop in my ziplock bag when I was out. Then I’d throw them out when I got home. I’d imagine I’d do the same with tampons if I were to go back to disposables.

snippet.textDisplay:
I use the pants for my really light days, I don't have to wear my cup at that point. Or when I'm at work and I can't get the bathroom, that way I don't have any leaks. It's good if you're going to bed in the evening It prevent leaks. Besides that, no it's not for heavy flows without Extra Protection. I would highly recommend wearing this product with a tampon or a cup.
I have a family member who wears the Thinx brand pants and that work perfect for her.
So I guess it's what works for the individual
But I would never recommend putting a sea sponge in yourself

snippet.textOriginal:
I use the pants for my really light days, I don't have to wear my cup at that point. Or when I'm at work and I can't get the bathroom, that way I don't have any leaks. It's good if you're going to bed in the evening It prevent leaks. Besides that, no it's not for heavy flows without Extra Protection. I would highly recommend wearing this product with a tampon or a cup.
I have a family member who wears the Thinx brand pants and that work  perfect for her.
So I guess it's what works for the individual
But I would never recommend putting a sea sponge in yourself
Sea sponge???

snippet.textDisplay: Please do an update of this video of non weird but environmentally sustainable menstrual items such as the moon cups as reusable material pads and different versions of decent pants like thinx brand. Please also do a disclaimer that it is not okay to flush anything other than tissue. Even those Andrex wipes that say they are flushable are lying and not flushable!!!! Because they don’t disintegrate and clog / block the sewers which takes public funds to fix which means our bills go up because the water ways are now privately owned. So the more it costs them the more it costs us. Phew rant over but given you didn’t know there will be followers that think that’s ok and it’s not.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm 56. I had a horrendous time from the age of about 11 until age 50. It wasn't so much a period as a tsunami every 22 days. Tampons and cups wouldn't have worked. I WOULD have liked the panties as back up, as I was running to the bathroom every couple of hours to change a big thick bulky pad. I leaked, A LOT. I missed a lot of school due to hideous cramps and nausea. Weird period products wouldn't have worked for me.

And I wrapped a LOT of toilet paper around everything. Menopause was a God send for me.
snippet.textOriginal:
I'm 56. I had a horrendous time from the age of about 11 until age 50. It wasn't so much a period as a tsunami every 22 days. Tampons and cups wouldn't have worked. I missed a lot of school due to hideous cramps and nausea. Weird period products wouldn't have worked for me.

And I wrapped a LOT of toilet paper around everything. Menopause was a God send for me.
